item.g:title: Svelato
item.g:material: Engraving on panel with chalk ground, 70x50cm, 2023

item.g:title: Atelier on the street
item.g:material: Oil, acrylic and papier collé on cotton canvas, 150x140, 2024

item.g:title: From a series "Power shifts"
item.g:description: This is a series of collages with my reflections on the key moments in the history of Russia, Russian society and the political agenda from the October revolution onwards. I am trying to find good metaphors for power in a particular period – a cult leader, an indignant peasant, a robotic factory-man. These illustrations are not meant to inspire cut-throat political debates, no more than the illustrations in the old, tattered encyclopedia. They are meant to make your minds wonder around the meadows of time, reflecting about the immortal shape-shifter; the spirit of Power. Power is like an innocent truck, it can destroy you if you are unlucky enough to find yourself in its way, unless of course you happen to be a concrete wall.

item.g:title: Series game with colors. Yellow blu
Black and white series. White on black 1/4
Black and white series. Black on white 1/4
KILLING
item.g:material: Stencil, spray, acrylic, on wood, 73X58 cm, 2023

item.g:title: SID & NANCY
item.g:material: Stencil, spray, acrylic on wood, 130 x 100 cm, 2022

item.g:title: SUNSHINE
item.g:material: Stencil, spray, acrylic on wood, 178 x 99 cm, 2022

item.g:title: SOLITUDINE CONTEMPORANEA #5
item.g:material: Stencil and spray on cardboard, 35x50 cm, 2020

item.g:title: Resilience
item.g:material: Stencil, spray, acrylic on cardboard, 121x76 cm, 2022
item.g:description: People who have made their body the perfect stereotype of strength and agility, of physical power and iron will, concentrated on dedicating much of their time and energy to its care. A constant and unidirectional training which, just when it seems to have reached the point of exhaustion, often unexpectedly reveals the resilience of indomitable warriors.

item.g:title: Weird Or Boring?
item.g:material: Stencil, spray, acrylic on wood, 146x76 cm, 2022
item.g:description:
Building on the body and on external appearances, or rather on their continuous transformation and redefinition; an essential element of identity. To amaze, to provoke, to escape from the obvious and cloying parameters of beauty of the shared imaginary body, aesthetically perfect but repetitive, escaping the constraints of a static beauty, for all uses and customs.
For sale

item.g:title: No Title
item.g:material: Oil and glass on canvas, 60x80 cm, 2023. Framed.
item.g:description: It is impossible to give a title to this work. Power and powerlessness are two sides of the same phenomenon. The greater the power, the greater the powerlessness. The greater the powerlessness, the greater the need for power. The greater the fear, the greater the cruelty.

item.g:title: Fairytale City
item.g:material: Oil and glass on canvas, 60x80 cm, 2021
item.g:description: Double-sided. The concept is based on the idea of the duality of Minsk and life in the modern dictatorship of Belarus. On the front side, there is a “postcard” Minsk with bright yellow vases, spacious avenues, green parks and the watery surface of the Svislach River. Looking at the other side of the painting, the picture changes, the illusions dissolve. On the other side, we see the truth about the city. It is black and white with a bloody red river.

item.g:title: Internal Segregation. "Heads of Democracy" collection
item.g:description: The artwork was created during the period of the Covid segregation. When human rights were grossly violated for the sake of a supposedly-caring attitude to health. An invasion of privacy took place. And if you do not accept this care, you become "untouchable". The state take care of you, but they deprive you of rights – this causes an internal dissonance. Internal segregation.

item.g:title: A Walk
item.g:material: Oil and glass on canvas, 60x80 cm, 2022. Framed.
item.g:description: Double-sided. The title and story refer to two famous paintings: Prisoners' Round by Van Gogh and Over the Town by Marc Chagall. On the front side we see the ferris wheel of the Minsk amusement park. However, the picture does not look cheerful. Even on a normal day, Belarus resembles a prison: half-empty streets, tense passers-by, police officers patrolling every corner of the city. An illusion of freedom has been created, that in reality are strict rules of conduct the violation of which leads to punishment. The red glass figure is the ghost of a free citizen who sees the situation clearly. If you peer into the figure, you can see the other side of this summer “walk”. The reverse side shows the current state of affairs. The vast park area turns into the walls of a prison which is impossible to leave. The police officers are the same. And even those who try to take a walk "above" – remain within the confines.

item.g:title: We left
item.g:material: Oil and glass on canvas, 70х70cm, 2022. Framed.
item.g:description: Double-sided. The front side presents the black windows of the abandoned houses of Belarusians who have fled from the Lukashenko regime in the last two years. Abandoned houses, empty black mourning windows. This is the pain of all emigrants who have been forced to leave their homeland without the opportunity to return to the places where they spent their childhood. The central window is made of transparent glass. This is a feature of my artworks: built-in glass, which allows you to "peep" into the visible part of the picture and see the hidden meaning. On the reverse side, there’s a gray square with empty glass on a black uneven background. This is the feeling of each of us, each emigrant. Emptiness inside. Isolation outside. Difficulties with adaptation. The windows of those who are on their own land are bright yellow squares filled with warm light. People living on their own land have a home. We do not have one. And just one black window among the joyful yellow windows is a symbol of an emigrant who has been able to adapt, to get used to the new place. But he still hasn’t become one of them. We feel each other.

item.g:title: Best-Maintained Building
item.g:material: Oil and glass on canvas, 60х80cm, 2022. Framed.
item.g:description: Double-sided. "Best-Maintained Buildings" appeared in the USSR. In order to get such a status, a house had to meet certain criteria (cleanliness, tidiness, chairman of the board of trustees of each block, participation in public initiatives, etc.). I used to live near such a house. I can’t say that for me it was so different from other houses. The same people lived in it as in other Soviet houses: they went to work, got back from work, did the shopping, raised children, some people stole at work, drank heavily, misbehaved and lost their temper. This picture is about the whole of Belarus. A “Best-Maintained” state. Behind the facades of residential areas, in each house there are the empty apartments of emigrants, the pain of those who have been hurt by riot police or security agencies, tragedies, prisons... Entrance number “23.34” is the code of an administrative violation clause about mass unrest, under which many Belarusians who disagree with the regime have been convicted. Nevertheless, on the reverse side, we can see one yellow window of hope.

item.g:title: Amphitheater of War
item.g:material: Polystyrene, cement, colored glass, smalt. 50х50 cm, 2022.
item.g:description: War is a funnel of real pain. It is death, blood, suffering. But life must win.

item.g:title: Infinite Mother
item.g:material: Sculpture (mosaics, clay, marble base). Height 32 cm, 2021.
item.g:description: Primitive Venus is a symbol of a life source. Mother is not only a life source. It is also beauty, aesthetics, pain, empathy, love – which have no end.

item.g:title: Targets
item.g:material: Oil, acrylic and glass on canvas, 60x80 cm, 2022. Framed.
item.g:description: Double-sided. “We are not shooting at civilians,” they said. The whole Ukraine is targets. But you have to open your eyes to see it.

item.g:title: Book “Aurora Borealis”
item.g:material: Hand-binded, self-published, edition of 28, size 20cm*20cm, hard velvet cover, 90 pages

item.g:title: From the project Aurora Borealis
item.g:description: The main monument of Murmansk is Aliosha. This is also the name of my son, and for me, it has never been just a monument or a symbol of the city. It is something much more personal. Aliosha represents the image of a protector, a guardian who protects me in my inner world. When I think of this monument, it becomes a connection between me and the place where I spent my childhood. My grandmother, who lived in Murmansk, used to tell me stories about this monument, about how it towers over the city and looks toward the Northern Lights. For her, it was like a landmark, a symbol of strength. For me, its name seems to intertwine with my life, creating surprising connections between the past, the present, and what truly matters to me. Aliosha of Murmansk feels as if it has always been there, reminding me that even in the most challenging moments, there is something that protects and supports. To me, this monument is not about heroes, battles, or war stories. It speaks of inner strength, of protection we feel at the level of the soul, and of how a name can unite the entire world of meanings.

item.g:title: From the project Aurora Borealis
item.g:description: My grandfather was a sailor. Once, he and my grandmother moved from the Mogilyov region to Murmansk for work. My grandmother also dreamed of working on a ship, but she suffered from seasickness, so she stayed in the city and found a job as a nurse. My grandfather, on the other hand, went to sea. He sailed on ships and sent me postcards from distant countries. Those postcards were my first contact with something far away, unknown, and dreamlike. My son Aliosha also dreamed of journeys and ships. He would draw them, write about them – it was his passion. I always saw something familiar in this, a continuation of our family line. Even after many years, ships have remained in our family as a symbol of movement, freedom, and unexplored horizons. A special detail: in my grandfather's work record, the date of his last service on a ship is February 28, the day of Aliosha’s birthday. The number 28 has become a symbol for me. It accompanies me through life as a sign connecting times, generations, and the stories of our family.

item.g:title: From the project Aurora Borealis
item.g:description: My grandmother had no children of her own, but she was the mother to all of us. Sometimes I think she is the beginning of everything: of what had been before her and of what came after. Her care still holds us together, even if sometimes it remains at the level of intuition and feelings. As a child, I spent almost all my holidays at my grandmother's house. I listened to her stories about Murmansk and the Northern Lights. She dreamed of taking me to the city where she had spent the most beautiful period of her life. She also dreamed of seeing my children. Her dreams didn’t come true in her earthly life but I believe that, in some way, we managed to fulfil them together in the multiverses.

item.g:title: From the project Aurora Borealis
item.g:material: 2022 Colour print RA-4 Image size 47,5х47,5сm Metallic frame, anti-reflective glass 1/10

item.g:title: From the project Aurora Borealis

item.g:title: From the project Aurora Borealis
item.g:material: 2022 Colour print RA-4 Image size 47,5х47,5сm Metallic frame, anti-reflective glass 1/10

item.g:title: From the project Aurora Borealis
item.g:material: 2022 Colour print RA-4 Image size 47,5х47,5сm Metallic frame, anti-reflective glass 1/10

item.g:title: From the project Aurora Borealis
item.g:material: 2022 Colour print RA-4 Image size 47,5х47,5сm Metallic frame, anti-reflective glass 1/10

item.g:title: From the project Aurora Borealis
item.g:description: Olga Zaverzhenets is an artist, whose work explores profound personal experiences, transformations, and transcendent moments. Her art is marked by the theme of loss, yet she always looks toward light and hope. Despite the passing of her son and husband, Olga has not given up. She has found a way to fulfill the dreams of her late loved ones, as well as her own. "Everyone has dreams. I always dreamed of the Northern Lights. My grandmother dreamed of coming with me to the city where she had lived before I was born. My grandmother dreamed of seeing my children. My eldest son dreamed of journeys and ships. I dream that we will always be together. Of the three of us, only I remain in this reality. One day, I realized that we could still make each other’s dreams come true." For Olga, the Northern Lights have become a symbol of the meeting point between the impossible and the real, a clash between doubts and hope. This project is her way of looking beyond loss, finding the light, and preserving it in her reality. "Aurora Borealis is the meeting of the unreal with what is happening now, a meeting of doubts and hopes. It is the eternal struggle within myself, the desire to believe, the intense desire to find the miracle I’ve been seeking, facing the walls of a rational mind." The Aurora Borealis project was born as a result of Olga's personal experience of loss in recent years. It is an exploration of emotions, pain, and the healing process – a journey in search of answers and hope. "This is my story, my search for faith, shaping of my worldview, and the desperate hope that we will be together forever." All the photographs were shot on color film, developed, and printed by hand. This process has become part of Olga’s personal ritual, similar to observing the aurora gradually appearing in the night sky. Aurora Borealis is a project of hope, demonstrating how light can connect us even through loss, and how strength can be found in suffering to continue the journey.

item.g:title: From the series "Secret"
item.g:description: My childhood is my village, my grandmother and the omelet she made. This omelet from her stove reminded me of a cloud. My grandma flew far away above the clouds and took all her secret recipes with her. Now nobody knows how to cook the omelet and I’m searching for this secret from other grandmothers. The grandmothers who are still with us. At the same time I am searching for other secrets that may be important for someone.

item.g:title: From the series "Secret"
item.g:description: My childhood is my village, my grandmother and the omelet she made. This omelet from her stove reminded me of a cloud. My grandma flew far away above the clouds and took all her secret recipes with her. Now nobody knows how to cook the omelet and I’m searching for this secret from other grandmothers. The grandmothers who are still with us. At the same time I am searching for other secrets that may be important for someone.

item.g:title: From the series "Secret"
item.g:description: My childhood is my village, my grandmother and the omelet she made. This omelet from her stove reminded me of a cloud. My grandma flew far away above the clouds and took all her secret recipes with her. Now nobody knows how to cook the omelet and I’m searching for this secret from other grandmothers. The grandmothers who are still with us. At the same time I am searching for other secrets that may be important for someone.

item.g:title: Untitled
item.g:material: Silver gelatin, image size 45*45, medium film format, edition of 10, 2/10. 2021.

item.g:title: Gazes
item.g:material: Gum bichromate, image size 53*36, edition of 10, 2/10. 2021

item.g:title: Hunt
item.g:material: Gum bichromate, image size 53*36, edition of 10, 2/10. 2021.

item.g:title: The Burial of a Country
item.g:description:
A country of dreams laid to rest – We were deceived by the dream of freedom. Now wings heavy with pain carry us off into exile. A sentence awaits us, Instead of hope.
If only I knew where I am. In search of the promised land, we began our Exodus. A generation scattered – to the West and the East. Scattered nests now lie empty. Because we refused The leaders of the old order.
The foggy path leads us away in search of answers – Now we are thousands, millions – hearts full of curses. Those who did not bow, Those who were not consumed by terror.
Those who, after exile, chose to return. Whoever is the last to leave – don’t turn off the light in the house. So we’ll know the way home Next spring. Back to our mothers.
And from the ashes, the fire will rise again. But for now – only clouds.

item.g:title: Endless Revolution
item.g:description: Today is May 12, 2024. It’s been 1,372 days since my revolution began. For me, it should’ve ended 1,026 days ago – but it didn’t. I’ve heard the lectures and advice: almost four years have passed – it’s time to move on. But…? During my first year in exile, I’d take evening walks through the tidy streets of Białystok. Few people, quiet. And then – click – your body is here, but your mind is back there... Scanning the area for a potential roadblock... "That tire over there – perfect to set on fire!" And then, just like that, you're back in the present. It’s not like that anymore. But even now, questions, memories, meaning – they still pull me back. That’s where it all started. That’s where the past was severed. After all, waking up where I am now – I can’t not remember WHAT brought me here. You celebrate birthdays, right? You haven’t left those in the past? A person lives because birth marked the start of biological life. The revolution continues – because it marked the birth of a self.

item.g:title: By a Gust of Time
item.g:description: The lost revolution became a thick dividing line in how I perceive life. My subconscious pulled off an interesting trick – now, I experience myself as something that was born on the first day of the revolution and began to rapidly take shape. I looked through old photos and realized I no longer feel like the person in them. Same with memories. My mind understands: yes, that guy was me. But it feels more like a documentary about someone who looked like me at different points in time. I don’t feel those moments anymore, don’t relive the emotions – like they were swept away by the fierce gust of that time, which turned everything upside down. And now – there’s a new self, new priorities, new ways of seeing things, new meanings...

item.g:title: Dialogue With Myself
item.g:description: It seemed that in a world of burning car hoods, revolutions had already provided the answers – who is who, what each is willing to risk, and what they're truly worth. I liked discovering myself as a worthy black silhouette walking the knife’s edge above the heads of enemies. But it turns out that the real danger is closer than expected – in those you’re open and vulnerable with. A stab in the back, and you’re alone in the kitchen at night. Annoying lightbulb hums. Time stretches into infinity. You become part of it. And so begins a long discourse with your most unsettling companion – yourself. A search for answers. A rethinking. A search for new facets of your inner self. Becoming someone new – and accepting that new version. The bulb goes out. Darkness. But then, sunlight. The emptiness begins to fill. What was old and worn-out becomes fertilizer for new life. Fate suddenly brings in wonderful new people and returns the old, irreplaceable ones to where they belong in your life. And life, light as a hot-air balloon, once again rushes forward – toward new challenges.

item.g:title: The Beautiful Faraway
item.g:material: Oil on duplicating ink on canvas, 50x50 cm, 2022
item.g:description: The childhood mini-series Guest from the Future left a deep impression on me. It instilled a kind of directive: change the world, make the future better. And now – the future has arrived. Instead of intergalactic travel – religious fanaticism. Instead of starships – the thunder of tank treads. Instead of hyper-intelligent humans – hordes of ignoramuses eager to drown the world in their own shit. Instead of a new world – piss-stained barracks. Instead of the melophone – Big Brother’s all-seeing eye. Instead of an open universe – walls and military checkpoints. Instead of boundless horizons – the rebirth of empires. Instead of a society of well-being – endless masturbation over “strong leaders”. And power-drunk, decrepit, stinking old farts terrorize the planet with a nuclear button. Welcome. Forgive us, robot Werther. We f***ed it all up.

item.g:title: The Country of Houses On The Edge (meaning “I’ve got nothing to do with it”). Variation 1
item.g:description:
I remember how, on the barricades, the lights of the houses shone for us – sometimes they glimmered, sometimes they cried out, supporting all of us with their warmth. But it was all too brief.
Soon, the sun of our freedom was swallowed by endless darkness. In its place came war, primal fear, and horror. In that gloom, shadows began to stir, hunting for our souls. Black figures grabbed us one by one, dragging us into their endless labyrinth of suffering.
Wrapped in that black curtain, we kept searching for light and warmth, longing to be comforted in this frozen hell. We knocked on the doors of those glowing windows, begged them for help. But all that came back was a cold, glassy stare.
The beams from those windows silently lit up our faces – and gave away our coordinates to the endless horde of those black monsters.
We never did win our freedom – So forgive us, sister, forgive us, brother. With the light of their windows, we were all betrayed by this treacherous country of the houses on the edge.

item.g:title: Original Sin
item.g:description:
The one who skillfully disguised himself as a victim demands ever greater pleasure, believing in his own chosenness.
And a new lamb is raised for the feast – by the very hand that once fed the killers.
Another is condemned simply for being born among murderers, for failing to change the course of fate, for not turning the river backward, for not standing firm against the fury of the maddened crowd.
And for not marching with the horde – though only seeking shelter to atone for sins committed by others – he was pierced with a spear.
He was nailed to a cross by what we now call politics. Hung between two thieves, for the crime of resembling them.
Crucified for the original sin – the last man of the tribe of wolves.

item.g:title: Split
item.g:description: This work isn’t about slogans or manifestos – it’s a snapshot of a strange state of mind that, I believe, many political exiles have experienced. Being ripped out of your familiar world in a matter of hours. The canvas captures that feeling: when physically you're in one place and time, but your mind unconsciously drifts hundreds of days and miles away – and you find yourself back THERE. You’re just walking to Biedronka to grab some mediocre Polish beer and suddenly think, "This would be a good spot to block a road…", "Bad position – no escape routes…" I don’t know how long these flashbacks will last, or if they’ll ever go away. But at the very least, they’re a clear reminder that there’s unfinished business – things that still need to be done. So I guess… I’ll see you again in the streets.

item.g:title: Progressive Introversion
item.g:description: Disappointment in the hopes once placed. Inflation of former everyday values. A radical, mutual misunderstanding. Exhaustion from trying to explain. Mutual contempt... The end of all attempts to understand or be understood. Withdrawal. A retreat into a vacuum – one that slowly becomes its own little universe, filled with its own meanings, its own values, its own understanding. The birth of a micro-universe, one that shines brighter than the world beyond the shell. Everything else fades into background noise.

item.g:title: The City That Fell Asleep
item.g:description:
An awakened dream perished before the night took hold. Eyes shut again – perhaps for long, dark years. The squares became overgrown with trembling weeds, And the cries of the streets fell silent in darkness and emptiness. Quiet. Darkness. Dread. Like burning rubber wheels once did, The cold gaze of the stars no longer warms my city. Once again, we, the millions, have fallen into a heavy sleep.
May you see in your dreams That you are walking toward us – Toward the coming spring.

item.g:title: PTSD
item.g:description:
Two years after everything happened, I’m only now beginning to feel like I exist in reality again – tentatively starting to piece together some sort of future. Still, I wanted to capture the state that kept knocking the ground out from under me during those endless, feral days of nonstop battles in my mind, alienation, and a complete re-evaluation of values. One kind of revelation for me was Remarque’s The Road Back. I never expected that war and a failed revolution would stir such similar emotions. And suddenly, you realize you’re not completely insane – because in this twisted world, that’s the norm. Highly recommend it. It helps. But what terrifies me is that, when war rages so close by, you understand – there will be thousands and thousands more like this. Maybe even worse. Because war, I imagine, hits the mind even harder. And for those thousands, life as they knew it will be ripped away again. Not daily life – but their entire worldview. And thousands upon thousands will return, night after night, to the place where their old life ended.
You watch someone else put down roots, Watch them grow and bloom Through the ice, Forgetting that terrible year.
You’d love to be like the rest, But instead, you search not for a friend – But for a battle comrade. Someone from the barricades and street fights.
Someone who knows How revolutionary rage makes blood surge. Someone who gets what it means to dedicate every day to the struggle – Outside of space and time, Outside the burden the bourgeois life, Who sacrificed comfort For war against the state.
And meanwhile, it's spring for them – they’re moving forward, They have sunlight and the moon, But to you, it’s all a farce. In your sky, Mars will rise. Your body is here, your head – still there.
Everyone back in place: The tires, the stones, the fire. And the battle begins again – Alone, With yourself.

item.g:title: Homesick
item.g:description: Over four months in exile. Even though I think of myself as a person of the Earth, I miss it like hell. Białystok is beautiful and tidy, but I miss the piss-stained courtyards of Serebryanka:) I dream of walking along the canal, having a couple of shots of Alivaria beer in that burpy bar by the market. Sitting on a terrace, staring out the window, I’ll be remembering how the tires burned at the Plekhanov-Rokossovsky intersection.

item.g:title: Human Resource
item.g:description: The archon's ambition drains the body of Mother Earth, sucking the energy of our warmth. Their all-seeing eye steals our sun, and their mouths consume our voices. Take back what’s yours.

item.g:title: The Senior Advisor Reveals to the Common People the Miracles of Legitimacy
item.g:description: “You have to understand!” (c) In case the artwork is sold, 3% of the price will be donated toward burgers for the members of the Transitional Cabinet.

item.g:title: Dictator! Memento Mori.
item.g:description: Having lost its glossy stability, the ship of promises is now stuck in spilled oil. Moss slowly eats away at the mortal flesh of the Caesar. The rays of bravado have vanished into the womb of an eclipse. The Cerberuses are already fleeing the City of the Sun. Respice post te! You’re just a man, after all. In the fields where your victims fell, poppies are beginning to bloom. And you’ve already pissed yourself.

item.g:title: The Land of Houses On The Edge (meaning “I’ve got nothing to do with it”). Variation 3
item.g:description:
We walked as one, our people, toward the sun – the sun that lit the path to our future.
Neither fear, nor sorrow, nor loneliness seemed strong enough to stop us. And yet, after some time, we found ourselves on opposite sides.
Lost among the abandoned homes, among the stench of the bog where breath had stilled, we wandered in search of ourselves, moving forward, then back again.
And the light that led us wasn’t the sun – but a mythical emptiness.
Instead of finding one another, we lost ourselves.
Could it be us – these submissive beings, impersonal voids, driven by despair into ruin?
Perhaps so… We’ve all become lost in the timeless fog of this endless land of houses on the edge.

item.g:title: Total War
item.g:description:
War is everywhere – the air itself is thick with it. Those like us turn on each other, Not where the whole land is burning, Where silence drowns in the barking of dogs Instead of in conversation, in understanding…
Just one more moment – And our inflamed minds have flown off into the distance. Our dreams have flown, too.
Walls have risen where bridges used to be. For a scrap of flesh, you and I will tear each other apart. He fights. She fights. They all do.
All that’s left is to shoot the sun – And bury us all in the ashes of this war.

item.g:title: Sky of the Slavs
item.g:description: One of the pro-Russian rock bands has a song with a nationalist message, “Sky of the Slavs.” But in reality, the sky of the Slavs looks like a brick wall on which the power structures of totalitarian regimes operate, ready, if ordered, to beat even the clouds and the sun in order to maintain the grey stability of their system.

item.g:title: Goyda
item.g:description: The painting depicts a warmonger and one of the main Russian exponents of imperialist ideas. The title of the painting refers to the battle cry that this character tried to promote to the masses during Putin’s rally.

item.g:title: Coronation of the stomach
item.g:description: The opposition to authoritarian regimes often views sanctions as the main method of struggle, believing that the poorer the population, the more open it is to revolution. In reality, poverty is the backbone of totalitarian regimes because people do not have a financial safety net, and the state, which has a monopoly on all branches of government, can easily and simply deprive a person of a job and the opportunity to find a new one, which essentially takes away one’s ability to provide for their most basic needs. Therefore, a low standard of living makes a person more dependent and loyal.

item.g:title: AWAITING UNAVOIDABLE GUESTS
item.g:description: I have been in exile for over a year now. I catch myself on the thought that I'm starting to forget what it's like to be THERE, inside a totalitarian regime. Therefore, I decided to record memories because this is something that should not be forgotten. Some people managed to leave the 'concentration camp country' before May 2021, before the authorities launched a full-scale backlash to the lost revolution. These early escapees could not fully feel the repetition of history. But I will forever remember this feeling, when you look at reports of recently detained people and constantly come across familiar names. It's the feeling when you change all the web accounts every two weeks because those in uniforms came for another ally of yours. In this moment you feel how they are getting closer and closer to you. The creak of brakes outside the window, steps in the hallway – rising tension. You understand that you need to change the situation, you try to deliver it to people, but they were told to wait for a trigger and wear white – it's a sign of helplessness. There is no fear for a long time because if you have an idea, it is not that scary. All that remains is an endless, painful feeling of waiting for the inevitable. Pushed out of the front door, broken balcony, trampling, screaming - the guests came for you, you are lying face down on the floor - oddly enough, relief. The wait is over...

item.g:title: Conversation between me and us
item.g:description: What is "I"? It is essentially a self-sufficient person. A formed microcosm with its own flaws, but also advantages, achievements and reasons for pride. The identity has no need to encroach on someone else’s property or to belittle others in order to elevate itself. The identity is aware of its weaknesses and strengths, and works on himself. The identity is aware of its subjectivity, therefore it is capable of answering for itself. On the other hand, there are individuals who have failed as personalities. They tend to form flocks or herds. Notice how complexed people like to speak on behalf of “we,” thus scaling their inferior “I”. Say “we”, and raise your voice and importance.

item.g:title: Collective portrait of Dorian Gray
item.g:description: The portrait of the state is the face of those who broadcast from the screens. This is a portrait of Dorian Gray brought to life. At first, they started with small lies. But they continued further, and the further they went, the higher the level they managed to achieve in their dense absurdity. However, this obscurantism also affects them. This portrait is a compilation of the facial features of the main propagandists. Unconsciously, the result was reminiscent of the Night King from Game of Thrones.

item.g:title: The hunter and the catch
item.g:description: It is believed that the main victims of patriarchy are women. But in reality, men suffer from it no less, becoming hostages of the gendered role of the breadwinner. After all, the “catch” is often lowpaid work, loans and lack of prospects. The “breadwinner” feels oppressed and inferior, and begins to look for alternatives for selfaffirmation. Some find it in alcoholism, some in domestic violence, and others look for it through involvement in the history and culture of great empires and the search for enemies. This is how chauvinism and imperialism are often born. This is why militant regimes actively cultivate patriarchal structures in their societies.

item.g:title: Last call
item.g:description: This work is devoted to the role of schools in the work of propaganda and the inculcation of ideology. Teachers are one of the most dependent segments of the population, therefore, they are forced to be the main conductor of the authorities’ political dogmas. As a result, the very people who are supposed to open up the future for children, bring their former students letters of conscription to the army after graduation, rig elections and subject fragile minds to olitical indoctrination.

item.g:title: Creation of light and the seven circles of Belarus
PROPAGANDA WAITING FOR GODOT
item.g:description: For a long time I was interested in the phenomenon of Belarusian propaganda. In the case of Russian propaganda, it is obvious that people just want money, but the motivation of their Belarusian colleagues was rather intriguing for me. It looks like, during the events of 2020, any sort of decency on the side of authority ceased to be appropriate. And this situation made it possible for especially unscrupulous mediocrities to fulfill themselves and find their place in the food chain of this vile decaying system. Violent screams from the screen make some people think that the talking heads actually believe in the shit they are feeding everyone. All this surreal life reminded me of Beckett's play "Waiting for Godot". Absurd classic. The propagandists themselves and their fictional world are reminiscent of Didi and Gogo, who, having believed in a certain Godot, are waiting for his arrival, but he does not come. And the noose descends from the branch.

item.g:title: RUSSIAN FEAST
item.g:description: Once again, the evil empire spread out the tablecloth for a bloody Russian feast. Once again, the meat grinders grind the mince without stopping. Once again, the empire gnaws the bones of its own and other people's children with eager crunching.

item.g:title: PATRIOTIC CRAZE
item.g:description: Patriotism is a terrible wild plant when it grows on soil that is missing reason. Cheap vodka goes much better with some glorious history to snack on. If you have some rich culture on the side, it gets even more dramatic. Many people have nothing else to be proud of but their roots, and they make this pride the crux of their lives. Fueled by alcohol, this frantic Berserk is ready to litter the earth with corpses, to attack anyone who dares to think differently like his worst enemy. And if there is no real enemy in sight, then a sick mind will create one out of thin air – some reptilians, Zionist Occupation Government or the planet Nibiru, or someone who simply lives better. After all, if you destroy those who doubt the "greatness" of your religion, it must be super pleasing to god. The true “greatness” of the empire shows itself in the hungry fights in the lines of provincial supermarkets. But don't tell that to a devoted patriot. As they say, patriotism is the last refuge of a scoundrel.

item.g:title: A WAY TO FREEDOM
item.g:description: The post-Soviet regimes are like the Minotaur, which drags the lives of young boys and girls through the labyrinths of the corridors of "justice" to be eaten. He knows no compassion, no mercy. It is impossible to negotiate with him because negotiations are alien to him. According to legend, Theseus went to him in the end, when he dealt with him once and for all. Because the Minotaur understands only his language - the language of power. Freedom is not gained in comfort. It requires the payment of a high price, otherwise it would be easy to part with it again. Therefore, the path to freedom often lies through death, suffering and prison. But so far the Minotaur is waiting for new victims...

item.g:title: COMFORT ZONE
item.g:description: It is not just rubber batons of the police that enslave people. A cozy sofa, an employment contract and a sweetly smiling bank employee who issues a loan for new equipment – these are the most widespread slavery precursors. A real prison is a glass screen that creates a cozy illusion of a happy philistine life. But true freedom and beauty lie outside this zone. Revolutions are not made if they can be ended by the starting rain or falling darkness. Proper revolutionaries cannot leave for the weekend or go on vacation because the wind of freedom does not blow into the vacuum of comfort. Only by putting at stake the old and familiar, can you build the new and beautiful. Yes, the risks are high, but they are definitely worth it. Finding comfort in work, loans and children is a way to doom yourself to lifelong slavery, and to leave children with no future.

item.g:title: CONCENTRATION FEST
item.g:description: Thousands of captive state employees flock to the main square of all the cities on every public holiday. The people come for bread and circuses - the pillars of political ideology. But the apex of the absurdity is that in post-Soviet states the authorities are so fondly concerned about the public cheer that they force people to attend entertainment events, threatening them with dismissal, deprivation of bonuses, and so on.

item.g:title: THE CULT OF SUFFERING
item.g:description: It's largely a dark comedy, but occasionally propaganda manages to hit the sore points of the masses. Notice how propagandists often refer to the welfare of the opponents of the regime. “This one is a fat banker, and here is a happy-go-lucky IT guy. And here is an insolent businessman.” Propaganda plays on the collective belief that one cannot be an honest man without suffering. We often hear complaints that IT people do nothing and get money, these philosophers philosophize, and the artists do not want to go to the factory, oh... The cult of homo (post) soveticus does not allow one to get joy from work but only to work mercilessly and suffer, and crawl home exhausted. Fighting is also forbidden - it is safer and more comfortable to hate. This is a cult of hatred but not the class hatred of a worker against the exploiter or a proletarian against the capitalist. It is hatred of the serf against himself and against those who dare not be a serf.

item.g:title: THE STATE OF POMPOUS OPENINGS
item.g:description: Belarus (like many sovereign parts of the former USSR) is a country of Grand Openings! We have a tradition of solemn, pretentious opening ceremonies for anything - sports complexes and palaces, ramps, benches and public toilets. But after all, it is not only the thirst for people's love that drives all kinds of chairmen, their deputies, deputy’s deputies and other "honoured guests" to organize such celebrations. These ridiculous festivities are organized with remarkable constancy. And their goal is to make a heroic, extraordinary image out of simple civil service subsidized by the taxpayers. Not a soul must suspect that it is just normal. The serfs must see this as a great gift from the superiors, a sign of their good will. It is not just a bench in the park! It is a benevolent message from the top of the social pyramid and his holy grace, the ruler of all rulers. A citizen must remember that the state is not an instrument in the hands of the people, but god the father, who punishes with one hand and blesses with the other. And sadly, it works...

item.g:title: ANOTHER MORNING
item.g:description: More than 2 years have passed since the failed revolution in Belarus, but the reaction from the regime does not stop. Every day, about 5 people are detained in the country for political reasons. “They” usually come in the morning. Someone was detained yesterday, someone was detained today, and someone goes to bed and does not suspect that he will be detained tomorrow. Tomorrow begins with another morning.

item.g:title: THE BASE OF THE PYRAMID
item.g:description: The authority of clubs is not as terrible as the freedom perverted by generations of people who reject any identity in favor of collectivism and basic needs. "What are you missing? Appreciate what you have!" - pay attention to the people that say this. They say this with the air of a sage who has understood the truth. They say this as if addressing an ignorant boy who does not know elementary things... It would seem that limiting all your desires to basic needs is a forced necessity in very harsh times. But no! Instilled from childhood, the concept of "little happiness" has become a second skin to them, it became their ideal, even a goal. For them, small needs mean salvation from the dangerous world and the relentless supervision of the state. This little world becomes an ideology. And this is truly tragic.

item.g:title: THE SYSTEM LOVES SILENCE
item.g:description: This is a phrase I once heard while working in a school. If you think about it, it is a perfect ideological slogan of the post-Soviet dictatorships. These regimes came quietly, without civil warfare or military coups. They came through the electoral route, under a completely democratic guise. Dictators advanced in small steps, spreading their tentacles, tying more and more people to the regime, suppressing one sphere of society after another. Oppositional voices were barely audible, and the silence was perceived as silent consent. This tangle rolls on, and vows to lead to a brighter future. But when it wraps itself around your neck, it is too late to scream. Silencing is not only a trademark of dictatorships. I see the same trend in seemingly "democratic" opposition ranks. These people also prefer not to be too loud. It is our authoritarian upbringing which taught us that noise is an attempt to sow discord, an attempt to revolt. Dictators are created by the people. So a habit of silence covers a small cocoon of emerging democracy with a bronze coating. But I am very glad that this trend is finally breaking. For when thousands are in prison, one must not only speak, but shout and throw stones. I hope this example will spread to local communities. One of the early attempts to limit autocracy was the creation of a parliament. Parliament comes from the word "parler" - to speak. And democracy comes from the words "dick to dictators"!

item.g:title: "A LITTLE ELEPHANT, SWALLOW TAIL AND THE BLACK GRISHA"
item.g:description: No, these are not the names of children's games. These are the names of contemporary torture practices. No, they are not only used in the post-Soviet space, they exist under different names in countries that are considered to be democratic, such as the United States. But it is the post-Soviet sadists in uniforms who came up with playful names for the practices of torture and mockery of people. This is some kind of crazy little world with overgrown maniacs. And it frightens me that this world is not somewhere on the pages of Dante's hell. It is here and now, not too far, and this hell is ready to open its doors in front of you, slam shut behind you, and never open again. Abandon hope, all ye who enter here.

item.g:title: THE NEW HERO
item.g:description: The elevation of new heroes into the national pantheon has truly become a tradition. Hard times call for exulted verses. But heroes are individualists, they receive power, and don't really want to give it up. They want eternal triumph. What was meant to be an instrument of representative democracy falls in the hands of such 'heroes' and becomes a screwdriver that tightens the screws, tightens the grip of the authority on the population. It is hard for the people to part with the image of a hero. They have to go through the stages of denial and justification. And then, when awareness comes, it is usually too late. It takes a lot of time to understand that leadership is not sacred, but functional.

item.g:title: NESTED PEOPLE
item.g:description: Despite widespread collectivism, mutual responsibility and other attributes of an authoritarian society, the society in the post-Soviet space is extremely atomized and in the face of danger everyone plays for himself. People hide in their cozy nests, they do not want to see and hear about arrests and repressions. They hope that this doom will not visit their home. But in the end the oppressors come for everyone because absolutely all the nests are visible to the predators from above.

item.g:title: STERILE CONTEMPORARY ART
item.g:description: In Belarus, there are "black lists" of artists who are deprived of the opportunity to participate in exhibitions because of their political position. A similar incident occurred at the annual "Autumn Salon" when some artists were banned from participation without explanation. However, instead of protest and solidarity, the rest of the artists pretended that nothing had happened. In fact, now the sphere of art in Belarus has turned into a prison camp. In prisons, people who cooperate with the administration are called "goats". In Belarusian culture today, alas, only goats remain.

item.g:title: "THE MOTHERLAND IS CALLING UP FOR A GOBBLE"
item.g:description: Russia is a terrible mother, a mother who devours her children. Her children, in their turn, devour the children of strangers.

item.g:title: AUTHOCRACY
item.g:description: Aυτός κράτος (Autos Kratos) – is a Greek term which developed into "autocracy". In the original, this term meant the sole and independent power of the ruler over all spheres of society. But in the conditions of the post-Soviet dictatorship, the term has acquired a new meaning. Here, the authorities have intimidated people so much that now they control people without direct participation. The invisible fist of power is now firmly imprinted in people's imagination, which has evolved into a total self-censorship.

item.g:title: STATISTICS
item.g:description: “Authoritarian countries are especially sensitive to statistics. Thousands of specially trained people painstakingly fill and overfill plans and schedules every month, and this never stops. Next month authorities will set the bar even higher, and of course, the bureaucrats will deliver. And so numbers, graphs, and reports fly out of printers in stacks. New successes are broadcast on TV, and they say that life has become better and more fun. Entire states today exist on paper, but in reality, they do not exist.”
